text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So the visit with me is just a placeholder so you don’t fall through the cracks. Patient: Okay. Right. Doctor: Okay? So I do that with everyone. text: Family Member 2: Mhmm. Doctor: That it's a pretty non toxic agent. So I think you could try one and if it really doesn't work in a half an hour, then take another pill. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Family Member 2: Okay. Family Member 1: And so like, now when he starts chemo or whatever and if he gets nauseous, I call M____? Doctor: Exactly. Yep. And you know, we'll make sure you have your prescription or whatever. Well, hopefully we'll have to give it to you so that, you know, when people run into trouble, it's always at 2 AM in the morning, right? Family Member 1: Right? Doctor: When you're like, “Uh oh, nowhere to go and no one to call.” So, first of all, you'll have that in your medicine cabinet. We'll make sure you have your nausea medication, because that's usually the thing that runs into trouble. Doctor: But things that are nausea medicines require prescriptions.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, but hormone therapy, uh as far as I’m concerned, it’s the worst part of the whole thing, right. It’s gonna put you into menopause, it stills your sex drive, it gives you hot flashes, and it slows your metabolism by you know twenty-five percent, so you have to decrease your calorie intake. And you have to exercise like a fiend, or you’re going to get fat, and you don’t want that. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um but the other thing is it just makes you more tired, you know. We’re making you into an eight-year-old guy – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: -temporarily. Family Member: For two years. Doctor: Yeah. Different people. I’m overstating it a little bit, but people are more tired. And uh, but people are more tired. And, and but if you exercise, it’s not as bad. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have the side effects of an increased heart attack risk. You don’t have, your bones don’t get soft, your muscles don’t go weak; you know exercise is the key here. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um, but um some guys have bad hot flashes. And some guys get depressed because their metabolism down. Um, but make no mistake, people keep working; they keep enjoying life; they’re just more tired. Family Member: Uh hum.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
